evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Direct historical evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H11, H12, H13) confirms crew members were physically present, reachable, and in communication during the incident, supporting the claim and favoring communication breakdown over procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence is direct and consistent

defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment was non-functional or communication was lost, this would favor R2_COMMUNICATION_BREAKDOWN.
If visual or audio warnings were effectively given and ignored, this might change the interpretation.

node.statement: Availability of trained ground personnel to supervise and assist pushback

assumptions: Presence of tug instructor and trainee driver implies availability of trained ground personnel.
No contradictory evidence indicating communication breakdown or environmental/technical causes.
defeaters: If evidence showed lack of trained personnel or inability to supervise pushback, or if communication failures were documented that explain the deviation.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1-H4, H8-H10, H12) shows trained ground personnel (tug instructor and trainee) were present and supervising pushback, supporting availability of trained personnel and procedural deviation rather than communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of communication failure or environmental/technical issues; some ambiguity in signal effectiveness (H8).

node.statement: Mechanical/control failure remains valid and is not contradicted by any defeaters in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scenario.

The tug instructor and crew actions and communications (H1, H2, H3, H8, H10, H12) suggest procedural and communication issues rather than mechanical failure. Environmental factors (H4, H7, H13) also contribute but do not contradict mechanical failure absence.
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of explicit mechanical fault evidence; reliance on procedural and communication history

node.statement: The identification of the environmental or marking deficiency must be robust against potential defeaters or counter-evidence within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_dynamic_und_t3_prefinal scenario.

assumptions: The small size and visibility of the TRP marking directly impact the robustness of environmental deficiency identification.
Communication and signaling methods are part of the environmental/marking context.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, adequate, and visible TRP markings and effective communication signals that were ignored, this would challenge the environmental deficiency claim.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, and H13 indicate that the TRP marking was small and visual signals for stopping the tug were insufficient, supporting that the environmental/marking deficiency identification is robust against defeaters.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in the sufficiency of visual signals and marking visibility

children_spec.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible at the location
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect the location to verify presence and visibility of required environmental markings; absence or poor visibility lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged
children_spec.test_procedure: Examine markings for signs of wear, damage, or obstruction; evidence of deterioration lowers probability

children_spec.statement: Environmental markings are updated and accurate according to current standards
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare markings against current regulatory and operational standards; outdated or incorrect markings lower probability

node.statement: Required environmental markings are present and visible at the location

assumptions: Small size of TRP marking implies potential visibility or adequacy issues.
No direct evidence states markings were missing or obscured.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and adequate to all crew members, or if procedural errors were clearly documented as cause.
If additional evidence indicated the crew had full awareness and visibility of markings and still failed to comply.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 indicate the TRP marking was present but small, suggesting markings were present but possibly not sufficiently visible or adequate, favoring environmental/marking deficiency over procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in adequacy and visibility of markings; no explicit statement confirming markings were fully visible and adequate.

node.statement: Availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to the crew

assumptions: Training on TRP implies availability of updated pushback procedure documentation
Crew awareness reflects access to procedural documentation
defeaters: If evidence showed crew were unaware of updated procedures or TRP markings
If documentation was not accessible or not updated

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H9 and H11 show crew were trained and aware of TRP markings, supporting availability of updated pushback procedure documentation to the crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement confirming physical availability of updated documentation; inference based on crew training and awareness.

node.statement: Environmental markings are updated and accurate according to current standards

assumptions: The presence of TRP markings and clearance as described implies markings are updated and accurate according to current standards.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were missing, obscured, or non-compliant with standards, or if crew reported confusion due to marking inadequacy.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7 and H13 indicate that the TRP markings exist and are known, with adequate clearance and visibility, contradicting the claim that environmental markings are deficient or inaccurate.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement on compliance with current standards; small size of TRP noted but not explicitly linked to inaccuracy or outdated standards.

node.statement: Communication devices used by the crew were operational and accessible

assumptions: Communication via interphone implies devices were operational and accessible
No evidence of device failure or inaccessibility was reported
defeaters: If evidence showed communication devices were malfunctioning or inaccessible
If crew members reported inability to communicate or device failure

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H8, H11, and H12 indicate that communication devices (interphone) were operational and accessible, and crew members were in communication, supporting the claim that communication devices were functional despite the coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct statement about device malfunction; assumption that communication via interphone implies operational devices

children_spec.statement: The mechanical components exhibit wear or damage consistent with failure modes observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA historical dynamic data
children_spec.test_procedure: Inspect mechanical components for wear or damage patterns and compare with documented failure modes in the historical dynamic data

children_spec.statement: Control system anomalies recorded in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA historical dynamic data match the characteristics of mechanical/control failure
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze control system data logs for anomalies and verify if they align with known mechanical/control failure signatures

children_spec.statement: The timing and sequence of failure events in the historical dynamic data correspond to expected mechanical/control failure progression
children_spec.test_procedure: Compare event timing and sequence in the data with established mechanical/control failure progression models

node.statement: The timing and sequence of failure events in the historical dynamic data correspond to expected mechanical/control failure progression

defeaters: If evidence showed verified mechanical faults or repeat malfunctions consistent with failure progression in the dynamic data.
If fault codes or bench checks confirmed mechanical/control failure.
If physical marking/location evidence was absent or irrelevant.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H10) shows the aircraft moved beyond the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite the tug instructor's control, indicating failure was due to procedural and communication issues rather than mechanical/control failure progression.
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence / ambiguity

node.statement: The mechanical components exhibit wear or damage consistent with failure modes observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA historical dynamic data

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical wear or damage consistent with failure modes in Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA historical dynamic data would change my mind.
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates mechanical component wear or damage consistent with failure modes; all evidence points to procedural, communication, or environmental factors (H1-H13).
outcome.uncertainty_source: missing evidence

children_spec.statement: Pushback crew was present and available at the scheduled time
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs and timestamps to confirm presence at scheduled pushback time

children_spec.statement: Pushback equipment (tug and related tools) was operational and ready for use
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance and operational status reports of pushback equipment at the time of the event

children_spec.statement: Communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were functional during pushback
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze communication logs and equipment status to verify functionality during pushback

children_spec.statement: Pushback procedures and documentation were accessible and available to the crew
children_spec.test_procedure: Verify availability of procedural manuals and checklists at the pushback location

node.statement: Environmental markings are maintained and not obscured or damaged

assumptions: The TRP markings were present and maintained as per H7 and H13.
Crew members' reports about the small size and visibility of markings reflect actual marking conditions.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the TRP markings were obscured, damaged, or not maintained, or if crew members explicitly reported inability to see or identify the markings, this would support environmental/marking deficiency.
If there was evidence of physical damage or obstruction to the markings at the time of the incident.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.
He commented that the TRP was quite small.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircrafts nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H7, H13) indicates the TRP markings exist but are small and possibly insufficiently visible; communication and procedural signals (H8, H10, H12) were inadequate or not heeded, favoring procedural or communication failures over marking deficiencies.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in marking visibility and adequacy; no direct evidence of marking damage or obscuration

node.statement: Pushback equipment (tug and related tools) was operational and ready for use

assumptions: Operational use of tug and tools implies they were functional and ready for use.
No reported equipment faults or bench checks indicating malfunction.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment malfunction or unavailability, or environmental factors like poor marking caused the incident, the conclusion would change.
If communication breakdown was proven to be the primary cause rather than procedural deviation, the assessment would differ.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H2, H3, H8, H12) shows the tug and related equipment were operational and used by qualified personnel, with no indication of equipment failure; the procedural deviation is linked to operator actions rather than equipment availability or malfunction.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence explicitly states equipment status, but operational use and actions imply availability; some ambiguity remains about communication effectiveness.

children_spec.statement: Crew members were physically present and accessible during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Check crew attendance logs, cockpit voice recordings, and physical presence records to confirm if all crew members were available and accessible

children_spec.statement: Communication devices and systems were operational and functional
children_spec.test_procedure: Review maintenance logs, system diagnostics, and cockpit recordings to verify if communication equipment was working properly

children_spec.statement: Crew members attempted to communicate relevant information during the event
children_spec.test_procedure: Analyze cockpit voice recorder transcripts and crew statements to determine if communication attempts were made

children_spec.statement: No external factors prevented crew availability or communication
children_spec.test_procedure: Investigate environmental conditions, distractions, or emergencies that could have hindered crew availability or communication

node.statement: Communication devices and systems were operational and functional

assumptions: Operational communication devices imply functional communication systems.
No hardware faults reported implies devices were functional.
defeaters: If evidence showed hardware or communication device failure or malfunction.
If there was explicit confirmation that communication devices were non-functional or unavailable.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
He knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.
He assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H1, H3, H8, H11, H12) shows communication devices were operational but communication breakdown occurred, contradicting the claim that communication devices and systems were fully operational and functional.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether communication device functionality equates to effective communication among crew.

node.statement: Control system anomalies recorded in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA historical dynamic data match the characteristics of mechanical/control failure

assumptions: No mechanical fault codes or system anomalies were reported in the provided evidence.
The pushback control was functioning normally absent contrary data.
defeaters: If verified fault codes or repeat malfunctions indicating mechanical/control failure were found in the aircraft's system data.
If direct evidence of control system anomalies matching mechanical failure characteristics were presented.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H10, H12) shows the aircraft passed the TRP due to inadequate visual signals and human factors, not mechanical/control failure, favoring environmental/marking deficiency over mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: lack of direct mechanical fault evidence; reliance on human factors and environmental marking interpretation

node.statement: Pushback crew was present and available at the scheduled time

defeaters: If evidence showed the pushback crew was absent or unavailable at the scheduled time.
If communication failures or coordination issues were documented as primary causes.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H9-H12 directly indicate the presence and availability of the pushback crew at the scheduled time, supporting the claim and favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: None significant; evidence clearly supports crew presence and availability.

node.statement: No external factors prevented crew availability or communication

assumptions: Crew availability is interpreted as presence and engagement of crew members during pushback
Communication includes both verbal and visual signals among crew
defeaters: If evidence showed that crew members were unavailable or communication devices failed
If there were environmental or marking deficiencies that prevented effective communication

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H2, H8, H10, and H12 show that crew members were communicating and aware of procedures, but visual signals were insufficient and no warnings were given to prevent the pushback beyond the TRP, supporting that no external factors prevented crew availability or communication.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in whether visual signals alone were sufficient for communication

node.statement: Communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were functional during pushback

assumptions: Presence of communication via interphone and headset operator activity implies functional communication systems.
No contradictory evidence about communication system failures is present.
defeaters: If evidence showed communication equipment malfunction or lack of communication attempts between crew and cockpit.
If headset operator or crew reported communication failures or misunderstandings during pushback.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin.
The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1, H3, H11, and H12 indicate that communication systems between pushback crew and cockpit were functional during pushback, supporting the claim and favoring procedural deviation over communication breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit mention of communication system failures; assumption that observed communications imply functional systems.

node.statement: Pushback procedures and documentation were accessible and available to the crew

assumptions: Training on TRP and roles implies access to pushback procedures and documentation.
Awareness of TRP through training equates to availability of procedural information.
defeaters: If evidence showed that the crew lacked access to pushback procedures or documentation, or were unaware of TRP markings due to missing or inaccessible materials.
If environmental factors or marking deficiencies were proven to have prevented access or awareness.

quotes.exact_quote: The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.
He knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H9 and H11 show that the crew (trainee driver and headset operator) were trained and aware of the pushback procedures and TRP markings, indicating that pushback procedures and documentation were accessible and available to the crew.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No explicit statement confirming physical availability of documentation; assumption based on training and awareness.
